note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in France, Paris was founded as early as the 1st century CE and serves as the national capital. (Britannica; Wikipedia)
Located in the Nouvelle-Aquitaine Region of France, Bordeaux was founded as early as 300 BC, and has served as the region's capital city since 745 AD. (Wikipedia)
Located in Belgium, Brussels was founded as early as 979 and serves as the capital city. (Wikipedia)
Located in Charleston County, South Carolina, Charleston was founded in April 1670 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Richmond County, Augusta was founded on June 14, 1736 and became the county seat in 1779. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Currently located in Fulton County, Atlanta was founded in 1837 in what was then DeKalb County. When Fulton County was created on December 20, 1853, Atlanta became its county seat, and it became the capital of Georgia in 1868. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

catDesc.term: Banking--France. Bellot des Minieres, Brothers & Company (Paris, France)

gloss.p: Located in Paris, France, Bellot des Minieres, Brothers & Company was an investment banking company in the 1860s. (Richmond Enquirer, September 18, 1860)

catDesc.term: Banking--Georgia. Bank of Fulton County (Fulton County, Ga.)

gloss.p: Located in Fulton County, Georgia, the Bank of Fulton was established in 1855 as a private financial institution. (Pioneer Citizens' Society (Atlanta, Ga.), "Pioneer citizens' history of Atlanta, 1833-1902," 1902)

catDesc.term: Banking--Georgia. C. R. R. & Bank Company (Atlanta, Ga.)

gloss.p: Located in Atlanta, Georgia, the Central Rail Road & Bank Company, now known as Central of Georgia Railway, was a railroad company established in 1833 that operated in banking services to attract capital investments to their railroad company. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Banking--Georgia. Georgia R. R. & Bank Company (Augusta, Ga.)

gloss.p: Located in Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia Rail Road & Banking Company was a railroad company established in 1833 that operated in banking services starting in 1835, as a way to attract capital investments to their railroad company. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Banking--Georgia. Savannah Bank of Commerce (Savannah, Ga.)

gloss.p: Located in Savannah, Georgia, the Savannah Bank of Commerce was a financial institution operating during the 1860s. (The Western Democrat, August 13, 1861)

Located in New Orleans, Louisiana, Brown, Flemming, & Company was a subsidiary of Brown & Company, a merchant and trading bank established in 1810 in London, England, and with many allied firms in the United States. (Wikipedia; John Crosby Brown, A Hundred Years of Merchant Banking: A History of Brown Brothers and Company, Brown, Shipley & Company, and the Allied Firms)

catDesc.term: Banking--Louisiana. H. W. Conner & Company (New Orleans, La.)

gloss.p: Located in New Orleans, Louisiana, and Charleston, South Carolina, Henry W. Conner & Son was a private banking business established in 1853 by Henry Conner Workman. (South Carolina Encyclopedia)

catDesc.term: Banking--South Carolina. Bank of Charleston (Charleston, S.C.)

gloss.p: Located in Charleston, South Carolina, the Bank of Charleston was a banking business established in 1818 as the Office of Discount and Deposit. The Bank of Charleston was South Carolina’s branch of the Second Bank of the United States. Following the expiration of the Second Bank of the United States, the bank sought out a state charter, and the Bank of Charleston was officially chartered by the state in 1835. In the mid-19th century, it was one of the most secure banks in the southeast and had a strong reputation. Following the bank's investment in the Confederate States of America, however, it was insolvent by 1865 but was able to reopen its doors by 1870. The Bank of Charleston was acquired by another bank in the late 20th century. (South Carolina Encyclopedia)

catDesc.term: Banking--South Carolina. Bank of South Carolina (Charleston, South Carolina)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Bank of South Carolina (also known as Bank of the State of South Carolina) was chartered by an act of the state legislature in 1812. Stephen Elliot served as its first president. Headquartered in Charleston, South Carolina, the bank also established branches in Columbia, Georgetown, Camden, and Abbeville and catered to commercial and agricultural interests. By the end of the Civil War, the bank had over $15 million in assets, over half of which were Confederate securities and currency and had become valueless. The bank’s charter was not renewed in 1866, and the General Assembly ordered its remaining assets to be turned over to the state in 1868. (South Carolina Encyclopedia)

catDesc.term: Banking--South Carolina. George W. Williams & Company (Charleston, S.C.)

gloss.p: Established in 1852, George W. Williams & Company was a wholesale grocery firm located in Charleston, South Carolina. This grocery establishment was one of many that George W. Williams managed in South Carolina. (Williams, George Walton, 1820–1903. George W. Williams papers, 1845–1907. South Carolina Historical Society)

div.p:
His Excellency
John J. Pettus
Governor of the State of Mississippi

We are authorized by Missrs Bellot des Minieres Brothers & Company of Paris & Bordeau, to negotiate the purchase of the cotton crop of the State of Mississippi for French account. The negotiation abroad embraces also the influence of the great Bel-gian Bank, the "Societe Generale" of Brussels.

As a preliminary step in so important an affair, we beg you, to indicate a committee of the most influential planters and Financiers to examine the basis of the proposition, and satisfy themselves of its integrity.

Messrs H. W. Conner & Co: Bankers New Orleans
" Geo. W. Williams & Co: Charleston.
The Bank of Charleston. "
